div1.head: PREFATORY NOTE.
div1.p:
Lewin, in his ‘Manual of Tibetan,’ 1879, preface, states: “Tibet and its language are still comparatively unknown ... the familiar tongue of the people, their folk-lore, songs and ballads are all unknown.”
Far from contradicting this saying, Jäschke, the greatest Tibetan scholar of his time, stated two years later, in 1881, in the preface to the third edition of his Tibetan Dictionary: “(To) the student who has for immediate object to learn how to read and write the Tibetan language ... existing dictionaries (are) almost if not quite useless.”
Since Jäschke's third edition, two new Tibetan dictionaries have appeared. Walsh in an article in the J.A.S.B., Vol. 72, Pt. 1, n. 2, 1903, reviewing the last one of these, the one by Sarat Chandra Das, says, p. 78: “Although the present Dictionary has fulfilled what it purposed to be, namely, a complete Dictionary of literary Tibetan, so far as our present sources of knowledge go, it does not fulfil the requirements of a standard dictionary of the entire language, and the standard dictionary of the modern and current Tibetan language has yet to be written.”
Laufer, ‘Roman einer Tibetischen Königin,’ 1911, p. 27 et seq., says: “We have here to open a road through the jungles, unaided and by ourselves; we have to work through text after text and note down expressions and idioms as we meet them,” etc.
Grünwedel in ‘Padmasambhava und Verwandtes,’ 1912, pp. 9–10, endorses Laufer's remarks and adds about the difficulty of translating from Tibetan: “Ignorance regarding the subject-matter, mistakes and misunderstandings in the text itself, and, finally, the insufficiently explored idiomatic element of the language, of which the history is as yet poorly known, these are the main shoals.... Of all the dictionaries only Jäschke's has really achieved something in the matter of idiom.”
As a matter of fact the printed materials available for the home student do not at present enable him, if without the help of a native teacher, to translate, accurately and without skipping the difficulties, any modern Tibetan book (not even the so-called Tibetan Primers in use in Darjeeling) if such books do not happen to belong to those excerpted in the existing dictionaries. Jäschke's, which is the best from this point of view, mentions only 25 titles of texts used as his sources. Comparing this with the more than 1000 titles quoted by Skeat as the sources for the material for his Etymological Dictionary of the
English language we at once see the inadequacy of such material in the case of Tibetan.
It is true that at present more showy results can be obtained by the wholesale translation of texts (more with a view to making known their general contents, than to the furnishing of a precise philological, lexicographical and grammatical analysis), and it is certain that the results of such work of translation would be more attractive and interesting to the wider public. Yet one of the most valuable contributions towards laying a sound basis for future Tibetan scholarship is the painstaking, laborious and to a certain extent inglorious and humdrum drudging away at small texts with scrupulous attention to the smallest minutiae, for a secure fixing of illustrative examples by co-ordinating correctness of text, full discussion of meanings, sharp formulation of definitions and subtle analysis of all questions and problems involved.
The following essay is a first contribution towards an attempt to serve such an ideal.

div1.head: I. THE SONG OF THE EASTERN SNOW MOUNTAIN.

div2.p:
In his ‘Mythologie des Buddhismus,’ Grünwedel gives on p. 59 the figures of a triad of famous reformers of lamaism; Rje Rin po ch&mlrcomma;e, better known as Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa, and his two pupils, Rgyal ts&mlrcomma;ab rje and Mk&mlrcomma;as grub rje. On pp. 70–72 he gives biographical notes concerning the three, and indicates their place and historical importance in lamaism. Günther Schulemann, in ‘Die Geschichte der Dalailamas,’ gives in chapters II and III a complete compilation of what is known about these three.
In the modern Dge lugs pa sect their historical importance has never been lost sight of and their memory is kept green by a universal prayer or invocation, still in daily use, opening and closing every ceremony in a Dge lugs pa monastery. In preceding a ceremony it runs as follows:—
gangs can shing rta'i srol 'byed tsong kha pa_//
dngos stobs rig pa'i dbang phyug rgyal tshab rje_//
mdo sngags bstan pa'i bdag po mkhas grub rje_//
rgyal ba yab sras gsum la phyag 'tshal lo_//
To the repairer of the Tibetan vehicle, Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa (the Onionlander),
To the true, strong, wise Lord Rgyal ts&mlrcomma;ab rje (Noble Throne-prince),
To the sūtra and mantra teaching master Mk&mlrcomma;as grub rje (Noble Cleverness-perfection)
To these three victorious (illustrious) Father and Sons (Family of three), obeisance!
In closing the ceremony the words la phyag 'tshal lo are changed into gyi bkra shis shog , ‘may their blessing be on us,’ ‘may they bless us.’
When the monks meet for gsol ja , collective or communal tea drinking, the last three words are changed into mchod pa 'bul , ‘we give our offering,’ said before drinking the first cup and whilst sprinkling a few drops in libation with two fingers, the thumb and fourth finger of the right hand. At the termination of tea drinking nothing is said at all. Except for these changes the formula remains the same for all occasions.
Another pupil of Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa was his own nephew Dge &hdotb;dun grub, about whom further particulars are given in the same passages of the two works cited above, and who may be called the first Dalai Lama, though not known by that title but by that of Rgyal ba, or conqueror. Yet it will be seen from the above formula that the three who are together called yab sras ‘father and sons,’ that is Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa and his two spiritual sons or pupils, are all three called rgyal ba . The expression yab sras has no doubt to be understood as a collective word like ‘group,’ ‘family,’ just like pha ma means ‘parents.’
From this dge 'dun grub a small poem in praise of his teachers, the yab sras , has come to us, which we now publish. Of mkhas grub rje it is said that he founded a formal cult of his teacher Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa, and it may be that his devotional attitude found a reflection in this poem, showing the attitude taken by his own pupil towards him and his two other teachers in his turn.
This poem occurs in a miscellaneous collection of religious matter (said to comprise about 150 leaves), in a work chos spyod (‘Religious Practice’), leaves 59, 60. I have not been able to see a complete copy of this work. In this edition the text is fairly correct and clearly legible. A small edition, complete in itself, of which I possess two copies (not quite so legible), offers several different readings which nearly all seem quite as good, and some decidedly better, than those of the larger edition. The differences shown by the two texts are, relatively to the size of the poem, so numerous and of such a nature as to preclude the idea that mere copying can have led to them. One is led to the conclusion that one of the two texts was produced
from memory and not by actual copying. We shall note the variants furnished by the larger edition, marking them B., whilst following for our own text, with one exception, duly noted, the smaller edition A. My two copies of the smaller edition would seem to be prints from the same blocks but for some difference in the last page. Whether the other pages are printed from the same blocks, whilst only this one last block has been, for one reason or another, renewed (and changed in the process) may be left undiscussed for the moment. Enough to make the general statement that great care should always be exercised before pronouncing Tibetan prints as made or not made from the same blocks, and that, indeed, interesting observations may be made on Tibetan typographical practices.
The title chos spyod is a very frequent one in Tibet, and indicates, like mdo mang (as in J. Dict., p. 273b, but not as on p. XXI a), a religious miscellany. The particular chos spyod from which our poem is taken is said to be one of the text-books which the Tashilhunpo tapas are required to learn by heart. The book with the same title which Laufer (Verzeichniss der Tib. Handschr. etc. zu Dresden, Z.D.M.G., 1901, p. 123, n. 135) mentions, might or might not be the same. As I have not been able to examine the title pages and final pages of the book, I cannot give any further information about it. chos spyod is the marginal short title.
Another Gelukpa prayer of almost equal popularity and frequency as those of the one quoted above, is the following which may be used as an alternative to the former one. It is distinguished from it in that not the yab sras gsum , but Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa alone is invoked in it. It runs:—
dmigs med brtse ba'i gter chen spyan ras gzigs_//
dri med mkhyen pa'i dbang po 'jam pa'i dbyangs_//
bdud dpung ma lus 'joms mdzad gsang ba'i bdag_/
gangs can mkhas pa'i gtsug rgyan tsong kha pa_//
blo bzang grags pa'i zhabs la gsol ba 'debs_//
To the unfathomable great treasury of love, the Down-Looking-One (Chenresi, Avalokiteshvara),
To the immaculate Lord of knowledge, Sweet-voice (Jamyang, Mañjughosha),
To the subduer of the hosts of devils without exception, the Master of Mysteries (Chanadorje, Vajrapā&ndotb;i),
To that crown-jewel of Tibetan sages, Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa,
To the feet of that (or: thee, o!) Famous Goodheart (Lozangtakpa, Sumatikīrti), we pray.
The chief difference between the use of the two prayers is that the latter is more in private use, whilst the former is more favoured in what may be called official meetings and collective acts of worship. The latter prayer is often used in a manner like the ‘O&mdotb; ma&ndotb;i padme hū&mdotb;’ formula, and cases in which a devotee vowed to recite this prayer once or more times a 100,000 times are known. The practical purpose of the latter prayer was thus defined by a Tibetan: tshe 'di la gzugs po skyid po na tsha mi yong ba tshe ring po yong ba dang _/_shi ba'i dus la yid dga' chos 'dzin la 'khrid rogs gnang*_// To ensure (bring, ask for) in (this present, earthly) life: health, happiness, absence of sickness, and longevity—and at the time of death a happy mind and a firm hold on (grasp of) religion.
The above form of the prayer is the printed one which is used by the monks to read aloud, mechanically and repeatedly, as a sort of prayer-litany, together with other similar matter, for the benefit of their clients, or also to ensure their own salvation. It is said to occur in a prayer-book called dga' ldan lha brgya ma , which I have not seen myself and about which I have no further details.
This prayer has also some variations in its final line (after the words grags pa'i ) according to circumstances. This line ends, when:
Opening a ceremony : zhabs la phyag 'tshal lo_/
Closing ,, ,, : zhabs kyi bkra shis shog_/
Before tea : zhal la (or du ) mchod pa 'bul_/
After ,, : nothing at all is said.
It is interesting to note that one of my informants interprets the above formula as indicating that Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa is the
simultaneous incarnation of Avalokiteshvara, Mañjughosha and Vajrapā&ndotb;i, and that these persons invoked in the prayer are not referred to as a consecutive series of separate entities, but as all embodied in the one Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa. My informant was very insistent about it that this is the general and orthodox interpretation of this prayer. The other two names of Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa are 'jam mgon bla ma and blo bzang grags pa .
The closing verse of our poem is also a prayer to Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa. It is also in use elsewhere than in connection with the present booklet and occurs elsewhere in print as well. My informant ascribes it to Gendundub himself and thinks that its wider use has spread from this booklet, though he cannot definitely assure that Gendundub himself did not appropriate it for the closing lines of his poem, taking an already current prayer to Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa. The latter theory is plausible inasmuch as the last verse is seven-footed as against the eight-footed lines of the rest of the poem. Anyhow, the statement that this prayer also refers to Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa alone, and is as such used and understood by all Gelukpa monks, settles a doubt we might otherwise entertain as to whether it is not addressed to the yab sras gsum , in which case its final line would have to be translated in the plural.
As to the edition, in the original the verses are not marked; they are evidently four-lined. The small edition has no divisions at all, except marking the lines, but the larger edition has in addition a ! (sbrul mgo = snake head) after lines 16 and 48. In my own text and translation I have by typographical disposition and by the introduction of title headings indicated my conception of the clever and very logical inner structure of the poem.
The text is followed by a short discussion of the variants in it, next by a translation, and then, my main business, by a full lexicographical discussion, in alphabetical order. This embodies in the first place all the new material, supplementing, amplifying, modifying, or even only questioning, the data in Jäschke's Dictionary, 3rd edition. For this Dictionary is, as far as lexicographical method is concerned, still superior to all other, even subsequent, Tibetan dictionaries, however much valuable and additional matter may be contained in the two latter. Jäschke's dictionary is as yet the proper starting point for all future lexicographical research. In this glossary I have also drawn special attention to contradictions in these three current dictionaries, those of Jäschke, Desgodins and Sarat Chandra Das, even to such points for which I myself have not been able to suggest a solution or about which I could not bring
new material. For the good of future lexicographical work in the Tibetan field, it is very necessary to point out as many as possible of the numerous existing discrepancies and uncertainties (especially relating to finer shades of discrimination and precision) so as to focus the attention of investigators on them. It is unavoidable that most of this work can only be suitably undertaken on the spot in consultation with educated, intelligent Tibetans, and not in European closets. The number of those in a position to undertake such research will, for a long time to come, remain limited enough. As indicated in the sub-title of this essay my own main object in writing it is primarily a lexicographical one. For this reason I have also incorporated in my glossary notes on side-issues and all sorts of incidental idiomatic ‘catches’ which cropped up in the discussion of our text, though not immediately connected with the poem itself.
As it seemed the handiest way to present all the results of my investigation I have also embodied all commentatorial matter, the philological notes as distinct from the lexicographical ones, under the same alphabet. The few syntactical remarks have also been wedged in in this list, though in their case the ‘Stichwort’ had to be chosen more or less at haphazard.
In the matter of oral information and illustrative examples embodied in this paper, my authorities are nearly exclusively my two Tibetan teachers Skarma Bsam Gtan Paul and P&mlrcomma;un Ts&mlrcomma;ogs Lung Rtogs. The first is a native of Ghoom, though of pure Tibetan extraction (K&mlrcomma;ams). He has resided for nearly a year in Lhasa, for another 3 months in Tashilhunpo (where he was Tibetan interpreter between the Tashi Lama and Capt. R. Steen, I.M.S.), and for 4 years in Gyangtse. The second is a native of Lhasa, where he resided till his 18th year, after which he spent 3 years in Tashilhunpo as a tapa. Then he wandered for 12 years through Tibet, Sikkhim and Nepal, after which he settled in Ghoom since about 1914. Until recently he was there schoolmaster (dge rgan) in the local Tibetan monastery.
Both these intelligent men have given me the greatest help in long, patient and painstaking discussions concerning the lexicographical and other problems presented by this present text, as well as by several others, which I hope I will be able to publish and discuss from time to time in the future.

C. The Variants.
The texts used were two small blockprints, nearly identical A 1 and A 2, and a large blockprint B.
On the whole A furnishes a good text and it may be used as the basis for the edition. Two curious cases of the use of ba for pa (7. 45) seem more than mere negligence of the wood-cutter
in connection with the badly printed pa'i in l. 13 (which looks also like ba'iba'i ) and also a pa like ba in l. 23. Inversely there is a clear pa —thapas—in l. 37 and a bor for por in l. 48. A 2 twice lacks the hook in rtsa (20, 24) and the naro ོ in lines 29, 47. These two latter variants may be due to deterioration in the blocks or the roughness of the paper, or defective inking. Otherwise A 1 and A 2 are practically identical, and except for the last pages (the last two of A 1 are condensed into a single one in A 2) the two copies may have been printed from the same blocks.
In 5 B writes lding pa'i for ba'i as authorized by the Dicts. But the question of final particles is still far from being satisfactorily settled. The Dicts. are on the whole much at variance on this point. Desg. gives as a rule a greater variety of them than J.
Some differences in the tenses of the verb are presented by the two copies of A on one side and B on the other. In l. 2 snyeg is the present tense as against the past form bsnyegbsnyeg in A. As to the sense both would do, and though the past form in Tibetan is better rendered in English by the present we may understand the past form as ‘has begun to rise.’ In verse XI B gives imp. forms, making the sense one of command whereas A has present forms giving a mere statement. The final sa in soms , however, is not recorded in the Dicts., nor the form sbyongs ; thul , however, is a regularly recognised imp. form.
'khrugs in l. 35 is a correct past tense. The form khrug (without an initial 'a ) as in B is not recorded, though 'khrug , present, might do equally well. 'khrel , l. 32, is not authorized by the Dicts. which all omit the initial 'a . The substitution of 'chad for bshad (38) seems to lack sufficient urgency,
though J. records a 'chad nyan pa ‘to listen to an explanation’ from Sch. A 'phung , l. 29, is correct according to the Dicts., not phung of B, though J. and S. Ch. D. give the alternative spelling.
In the treatment of grammatical particles A is superior to B. par (10) is correct, not pa B. It is an adverbial construction. In 18, par , and 22, bar , equally so. In 24 par is a terminative dependent on bgyid pa .
The remaining variants are all in the nature of equivalents for or against which nothing (or the same!) can be said, and which would do as well as the readings we have adopted. Many of them are, however, curious for this reason, that they are not homonymous variants at all and consequently substitutions for, not corruptions of, the text. We have to leave the question alone whether those in A or in B are likely to be the original ones.
In 7, drin po che , very kind, is as good as rin po che , very precious; in 17 dus 'di nas means practically the same as dus deng nas , ‘from this moment’, and ‘from this very day.’ In 19 gzhan du ‘in another’ seems even a trifle better than gzhan nas ‘from another.’ gyis seems better in 32 than kyang in B, ‘even, indeed!’ byed pa ‘to perform,’ in l. 34, is as good as bsgrub pa , also ‘to perform, accomplish,’ and the future form of the latter would be better if changed into a pf. form bsgrubs or pr. sgrub . In l. 40 gtong ba , ‘the sending, throwing,’ seems as good as skyel bzhin , ‘(as silly) as the conveying.’ In 41 the article pa means the same as plural rnams B. In 44, bdag 'dzin , ‘egotism, selfishness,’ is substituted for nyon mongs ,
‘sin’; similarly in 45 and 49 kun ‘all,’ for rnams ‘many.’ Lastly, the difficult construction lhung bas ma 'chang bar , in 46, is replaced in B by the easier lhung bar mi byed par , ‘not allowing (letting, making) it [the soul] (to) fall’ instead of ‘letting it remain fallen when once it has done so.’
All these examples seem to point out that one of the blockprints (probably the larger one) was derived from a version which was not actually copied from the original but rather written down from memory. The variants are no cutting or copying mistakes except nges so and ngas so l. 16, and drin po che and rin po che in l. 7.
In l. 26 we find an erroneous cing for zhing .
The two ! at the end of lines 16 and 48 in B (or rather at the beginning of the following lines, for that is where they must be put if the Tibetan text is printed line for line like English verse) do not agree with my conception of the structure of the poem as indicated by my typographical arrangement of it. I would not have expected a ! after line 16 but after lines 12, 24, 36 and 48. The occurrence of the sign after line 48 may, however, be taken to indicate that the next two verses have to be regarded as appendices to the body of the poem proper.
It must be mentioned that in the title, in both copies of A., the final word is bzhugs . In B., as the poem occurs in the body of the volume, there is no equivalent title. I have written bzhugs soX without prejudice to the question whether the form bzhugs is legitimate or not. My teachers say that before a // the so is required.
The only reading taken from B is nges for the incomprehensible ngas of A 1 and 2, in line 16.
It may be, finally, remarked that the three copies from which this edition was prepared, show once more that textual
correctness and perfection of typographical execution are not necessarily related in Tibet. The two small prints which are, but for the single omission of a dengbu in line 16, quite correct, are small, badly printed on bad paper, and not carefully or neatly cut. D. Translation.
The Song of the Eastern Snow Mountain.
OBEISANCE TO THE TEACHER.
I. (His Teachers).
1. On the peak of the white snow mountain in the East
A white cloud seems to be rising towards the sky.
At the instant of beholding it I remember my teacher (or: teachers).
And, pondering over his (or: their) kindness, faith stirs in me.
2. To the East of where that cloud is floating,
In that entirely victorious Virtue Solitude,
There resided the precious ones, difficult to be invoked,
Father Famous Goodheart, the Sire with (his two spiritual) sons.
3. The yoga and other (teachings) of the two stages of the road
Relating to the profound Doctrine, they preached most fully.
To the pious of snowy Tibet
Your grace, O protectors, was ineffable.
II. (Himself).
4. Especially that this ease-loving Clergy-Perfection
Has turned his mind a little towards the Doctrine
Is (thanks to) the kindness of these noble father and sons.
Truly your kindness is great, O father and sons.
5. From now onward till (I reach) the heart of saintship,
Whilst, except in you, noble father and sons,
I will not place my hope for protection in anyone else,
I pray you to drag me along with your mercy-hook.
6. Though I cannot repay you in proportion to whatever your favours have been,
I pray that, with my soul not enslaved by attraction or repulsion,
I may hold fast to your teaching, O protectors,
And may always put my best energy into the endeavour.
III. (His Contemporaries).
7. However, nowadays, in this snow mountain solitude,
(There are those who) whilst promising to follow the teaching themselves,
Regard others, who (equally) follow the teaching, as their veriest enemies.
Such conduct calls forth the deepest sorrow.
8. With thoughts wishing the ruin of others
And with souls fettered by fierce ambition,
They nevertheless promise to dwell on the high road.
If we consider this (carefully) it is a matter of shame for all concerned.
9. These malignant beings,
Angry because they find themselves in their old age in the wrong road,
And raging from the bottom of their hearts
Against those persons who have (duly) acted conform to the Doctrine,
Has not a demon entered their minds?
IV. (His Pupils).
10. Not to take steps to conquer the enemy, sin,
But yet after mere reproach to flare up in reply,
That is as silly as,
When an evil spirit is at the Eastern door,
To throw the ransom towards the Western door.
11. Those virtue-friends who understand that this is so,
Think of all embodied beings in general with kindness,
But saintly thoughts especially of all who devote themselves to the Doctrine.
And they subdue the enemy residing within, sin.
12. O, my followers and friends,
Whilst not letting your souls remain fallen after a lapse,
But whilst examining (yourselves constantly) whether your minds keep to righteousness,
To remain on the straight road, that surely is good.
V. (Final Prayer).
13. May all those who believe in these words,
With a mind bent on the drawing on of all beings by means of love and mercy,
Through the (direct) vision of the actionless state of (pure) knowledge,
Speedily obtain (that) glorious, supreme saintship.
VI. (Final Blessing).
14. He, whose body blazes with the marks and beauties (as of a Buddha),
Whose speech is adorned with the sixty branches of melody,
Whose deep and wide mind, indeed, is a treasury of omniscient love,
May that glorious teacher's blessing be on us.
The above was composed by the Great Omniscient Clergy Perfection Good-Glory as a song in loving memory.
Blessing.
E. Glossary and Notes.
(Lexicographical, Syntactical and Material.)
kug see kyu .
kun gyis khrel ba'i rgyu , 32. Not so much ‘a matter of shame to all’ (= all the people who look at or into the matter, the beholders, the general public, or even humanity in general), but rather ‘a matter of all (of them) being ashamed,’ i.e. the people doing the shameful acts, the people concerned, engaged in this conduct, not the public in general.
kun slong , 29. Here thought, conception, wish (cf. D. opwelling). (Desg. ‘all-enveloping,’ i.e. ‘natural corruption or sin,’ p. 8b, but kun slong = nyon mong gi slong , ‘excitement of passion’ on p. 1044a). See also S. Ch. D., p. 29b, samutpadasamutpaada, but Schroeter, p. 2b, ‘approbation, assent, the consenting to any proposition.’
ko ko see glud .
kyang , 30. Here equal to yin na yang , ‘yet, however, nevertheless.’
kyu , 20. Not as a separate word in J., who gives kug and kyo ba , the latter after Schmidt. This is the word occurring in the compound zhabs kyu the Tibetan u-vowel, the ‘foot-hook’ (not merely honorific of kyu as Hannah seems to suggest in his Grammar of the Tibetan Language, p. 4), which J. has under zhabs , on p. 472a, together with a queried meaning ‘spur’ (of the foot: ‘ein Sporn’), taken from Csoma. This latter meaning is unknown to my informants. Bell gives: hook kug ; fishhook nya kug , but iron hook lcags kyu . Henderson gives both khug and kyu for hook, and also lcags kyu alone for iron hook. My informants deny the correctness of khug . Desg. knows kug (pa ) only as a verb, not as a subst.; he mentions kyu as a separate word, subst. hook, and does not mention kyo ba . The various articles in the three Dicts. sub khug are interesting but the meaning hook is not given in any of them. S. Ch. D. translates kyo ba with ‘a"nku"sa, a pointed iron hook, a large pin to pierce with,’ whilst Macdonell in his Sk. dict. translates the Sk. word as ‘hook, goad, stimulus, remedy.’ (See below s.v. 'dren pa .) J. under kug gives also lcags kug , an iron hook, and nya kug , a fishing hook, but my informants say that the colloquial for fish hook is rather nya 'dzin ya'i (or pa'i ) lcags kyu or simply nya 'dzin (pr. nyendzin), just as a meat hook (to hang up meat on) is sha 'dzin (pr. shendzin). The ya in
the above represents the pronunciation of the more illiterate people.
One of my informants is, however, of opinion that lcags kyu does not mean an iron hook at all, but hook in general even though it might be made of silver, copper, gold, etc. He compares it with the word wall, lcags ri , which is not necessarily made of iron, and though of stone or earth is still called ‘iron-mountain.’ Women's ornaments such as earrings, chains, or necklaces (ske 'phreng , pr. kenthang, not in the Dicts. or Bell. As a colloquial word the dengbu might perhaps be left out in writing) may have golden or silver hooks, gser gyi lcags kyu or dngul gyi lcags kyu . Example: skye dman 'di la skye 'phreng yag po cig 'dug/_de la gser dang dngul gyi lcags kyu bzhi 'dug , this woman has a very fine necklace which has four golden and silver hooks (or clasps). Schroeter's dict., p. 361b, already gives lcags kyu as hook only. The expression lcags nag in the sense of mineral, given by Desg., 307a, would make us think that lcags kyu might perhaps mean metal hook, but see below. S. Ch. D. adds to the confusion. Under lcags kyu he gives: (1) iron pin to guide and punish elephants; fish-hook; (2) name of a plant. (His next entry seems improbable, elephant driving and elephant driver for one and the same word). But under kyu he defines lcags kyu as ‘iron hook, an angle, a fishing-hook.’ J. has lcags kyu under lcags and gives ‘an iron hook, esp. fishing-hook, angle; often fig.’ and in his illustration he translates chos kyi lcags kyu simply as ‘hook of grace.’
He marks the word as belonging to the book language. It is curious to note that Schlagintweit in his Rgyal-rabs (title, or introductory verse) translates the word lcags kyu with ‘eisernen Hacken’ (p. 25), whilst Schiefner renders the same word correctly on the next page by ‘Hacken’ alone. But in his new translation of the Rgyal-rabs, H. A. Francke (J.P.A.S.B., Vol. VI, n. 8, p. 397) writes again ‘Iron Hook.’
There is still another compound with kyu , namely mtheb kyu , the name for a component part of the elaborate torma cake structure. It indicates a small piece of dough in the form of the top of the thumb. From all these examples it might be hazarded that the element kyu means primarily ‘curve, curved’ or ‘curvature,’ and has no substantial meaning like ‘hook’ or the like. My teachers, however, think that kyu by itself is a substantive ‘hook.’ So it is not clear whether J. is right as against the other Dicts. in not entering the word separately. The above discussion is in any case better entered under the word kyu , whether this is really an independent word or not. The fact that S. Ch. D. gives a Sk. equivalent for kyu alone, pleads for its separate existence.
My teachers opine that kyu as a separate word may occur alone, but their nearest approach to framing a sentence illustrating such a use was one in which they spoke of a wooden hook (made by a jungleman to fish or hunt with) as shing gi lcags kyu or more briefly shing kyu . So the example was not decisive.
Additional Note—Cf. the example in Csoma's Grammar, p 109: gser gyi lcags sgrog , golden fetters or chains, lit.: golden iron ropes. See also Ramsay, ‘Western Tibet’, p. 62:
‘To hook—ngiákuk táng ches, properly applicable only to a fish caught with a hook, but also used generally’, and:
‘Hook—ngiákuk (fish hook), kuk kuk (a hook of any kind)....’
Query: Is the use of lcags merely conventional in several words, as in lcags khra , cage (Bell, Walsh ‘Tromowa Dialect’), lcags zam (iron) bridge, etc.? And is the use of lcags perhaps analogous to that of honorific prefixes? Cf. the Dutch guilder (gulden) which is made of silver, though its name is derived from ‘gold.’
kyo ba see kyu .
dka' ba , 7. Difficult, but here rather with some of the meaning of the English ‘hard’ (hard lines?), the French ‘dur’, perhaps L. ‘arduus.’ The meaning is somewhat that the invocation should not be undertaken lightly (God's name should not be spoken ‘in vain’). Conceptions like: grave, serious, weighty, not lighthearted, or commonplace, or flippant, suggest themselves here. It is ‘a serious matter’ to invoke these teachers.
bka' drin sems pa , 42. To think with kindness of or towards, or about (la ).
skal ldan , 11. We have taken this word in the general sense given by J. ‘the pious,’ though it may equally well be rendered by ‘the fortunate ones,’ i.e. those who were fortunate enough to hear Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa's preaching or that of his two pupils. One of my informants suggests, however, that skal ldan should here be taken more literally as ‘sharers’, ‘share-havers’ in Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa's message and consequently should here be understood as his ‘followers.’
sku glud see glud .
ske 'phreng see kyu .
skyabs re sa , 19. May either be taken as two separate words ‘protection and hope’ or as a compound ‘hope for protection,’ ‘protection-hope.’ More accurately ‘the spot (place = persons in this case) in whom I place my hope for protection, to whom I resort or go, in whom I trust, for protection.’ (cf. D. heul, toeverlaat).
skyid glu see mgur ma .
skye sgo see sgo .
skye ba , 4. This is an illustration of the meaning of skye ba under J.'s 4th sub-heading, 1st division. dad pa skyes ‘faith has been born,’ but here rather ‘becomes active,’ ‘sprouts,’ ‘waxes strong,’ or ‘grows, flames up, intensifies, awakens, arises, stirs.’ The idea is not, as in a case of Christian conversion, of a state of previously non-existent faith, suddenly arising, but of an existing faith becoming strongly energised, leaping up (‘an outburst of faith’). The colloquial dad pa skyes can be suitably translated by ‘to inspire faith to.’ For instance bla ma 'di la dad pa skyes kyi (mi ) 'dug , that lama inspires me with (no) faith. A free translation of dad pa skye ba is consequently ‘to have faith in,’ but in our passage the additional meaning of ‘renewed’ is implied. Therefore we may also render ‘they call up my faith’ or ‘renewed faith comes up in me.’ See the use of this expression in the Tibetan Primer III, p. 7, 1. 8. de nas kho (read khos ) rgyal po de shin tu bzang por shes te dad pa skyes te phyag grangs med 'tshal nas rgyal pos gnang ba de rnams bdag ga la zhu_/ Then he, recognising that the king was very good, and having gained faith in him, and having prostrated himself numberless times, (asked) how can I request (i.e. take, accept) such (gifts) given by the king.
skyed sgo see sgo .
skyed pa , 50. To generate, the generation, production. sems bskyed pa ‘that which has been produced in the soul,’ ‘the (completed) productions of the soul’; with dang = with; ‘with thoughts of, assuming, observing an attitude of, with a mental attitude of or disposition to.’ 'gro ba rnams byams snying rjes drangs
pa'i sems bskyed (dang ) is one elaborate substantive, a ‘the-beings-with-kindness-having-drawn-soul-disposition.’
skyo ba , 28. Here not in J.'s sense ‘to be weary,’ but as Desg. and S. Ch. D. have it ‘sadness, grief, sorrow,’ or adj. ‘sad’, etc. In seeing a half-naked beggar, it may be said: mi 'di skyo ba la kho la dug log yang mi 'dug . Here the word is adjective: ‘that unhappy (unfortunate, wretched, miserable) man has not even a coat.’ [dug log (Bell) = J. dug po = gos lag = chu pa = Desg. cho pa , coat, garment, dress; not alone ‘man's coat,’ as J. has it, but for both sexes—J. s.v. chu pa . chu pa and cho pa both missing in S. Ch. D. gos lag is pronounced both golak and gölak. Walsh, Vocabulary Tromowa Dialect, s.v. coat ‘go’ and ‘golag.’ My teachers do not know a word dug po for coat in Tibetan. Desg. has a dugs po , overcoat. S. Ch. D. dug pa* or dug po ‘old coat or garment patched up and mended.’]
ga gdan see gdan .
kha rtsod see gshags 'gyed pa .
kha gshags 'gyed pa see gshags 'gyed pa .
khug see kyu .
kho bo'i rjes mjug grogs po rnams , 45. My followers and friends (cf. citizens and compatriots), i.e. followers who are also my friends; the same people under two qualifications, not two different groups of people, the friends and the followers. See rjes mjug pa .
kho mi glud yin see glud .
khyed 18, khyod 12, 23. The difference in form is not accidental. mgon khyod is a stereotyped lab lugs , manner of speech, expression. yab sras khyed*, l. 18, is a normal honorific form. The form khyod was described to me as one of intimacy, of utter confidence, as distinct from familiarity and lack of respect. This seems an almost exact parallel to the use of (thou), tu, du in (English), French and German in addressing parents, God, and relations. The following example was given, a quotation from the bla ma mchod pa'i cho ga , a little ritual gelukpa book, leaf 12a: khyod ni bla ma khyod ni yi dam khyod ni mkha' 'gro chos skyong ste_/ ‘As thou art our lama, our yi-dam, our &ddotb;ākinī, our dharmapāla ...’ (prayer addressed to Tso&ndota; k&mlrcomma;a pa). Likewise, in the little prayerbook rje btsun sgrol ma'i gdung 'bod (to Tārā) we find a few cases of khyod (e.g. p. 5b) amidst many cases of khyed . In the term yab sras khyed the hon. form of the first two syllables of course determines the hon. form of the last. The ‘intimate’ form khyod was further described as ‘the language of religious transport, ardour, fervour,’ dad pa'i yus .
khrel gad (rgyab pa ) see khrel ba .
khrel dgod see khrel ba .
khrel ba , 32. According to the Dicts. ‘to be ashamed.’ Desg. and S. Ch. D. do not support J.'s meaning ‘piety’ and his third meaning ‘disgust, aversion.’ My oral information rejects these second and third meanings, yet see below. kun gyis khrel ba'i rgyu , freely translated ‘is a matter of (cause for) shame to all,’ literally ‘a-by-all-shame-feeling-cause,’ i.e. all should feel ashamed. The shame, it should be understood, must be felt, not by all who behold the bad behaviour, but by all who
are guilty of it. The exact meaning of the root khrel from which the verb is derived is not yet satisfactorily dealt with in the Dicts. which are supplementary as well as contradictory in their data. The compounds exhibit a great variety of shades of meaning. That of khrel med , for instance, may perhaps cover so wide a range as ‘shameless, impudent, self-willed, stubborn, stiff-necked, arrogant, insolent, ungrateful, loveless, heartless, harsh, cruel, wanton, ruchlos, frech.’ Some of the compounds and applications clearly indicate that khrel must also mean ‘sexual modesty, chastity,’ others that it must mean ‘bashfulness, shyness, timidity’ (in this sense khrel med ‘brazen, forward, unabashed, saucy, bold, audacious’). khrel seems to come very near to the D. ‘schroom’ which is more ‘diffidence’ than ‘scruple,’ but khrel med may in some cases mean ‘unscrupulous’ or ‘without a conscience.’ In this sense it comes near to ‘impious.’ The German subst. ‘Scheu’ may be also compared. It is also averred that in certain combinations a positive statement with khrel med is practically identical with the English exclamation: how dare you! how can you!
A compound, difficult to define exactly, is khrel gzhung med in which gzhung has the meaning, not given in the Dicts. of straight, straightforward, honest, true, dependable, the French ‘droit’ (cf. rectitude). The whole expression may mean ‘abandoned,’ or simply khrel med . Example khrel gzhung med pa'i mi de yi tshe de don med red , ‘the lives of these abandoned (shameless, etc.) men are useless.’ An old sweetheart who has cast off her lover may be called khrel gzhung med ‘the brazen, perfidious girl.’ Desg. gives gzhung in this sense as equal to bzang , ‘good, just, generous.’ This may be Schmidt's gzhungs pa ‘sincere, orderly.’ In the sentence pha ma la sku drin 'di 'dra log
pa de khrel med kyi sems red , ‘to repay your parents kindness in this way shows a lack of gratitude,’ my teachers explain the word as ‘ungrateful, loveless, harsh.’
As far as the further meanings of khrel , as given in J. (see above), are concerned, P&mlrcomma;un Ts&mlrcomma;ogs maintains that khrel sems can = chos sems can , ‘pious,’ but Karma denies it, and the former also states that khrel yod pa = zhen pa log pa , which latter expression Desg. and S. Ch. D. know as ‘to be disgusted with.’ But J. and the others render the former expression with khrel , as ‘chaste’ or ‘modest,’ or as ‘to be chaste,’ etc. Both of my teachers are at one about the expression zhe khrel ba ‘to be weary, tired, sick of.’ Examples: lto chas 'di la zhe khrel song , I am tired of this food. (lto chas , pr. tobché, see Henderson's Manual, Voc., p. 48, s.v. food; there written ltob chas .) mi 'di la zhe khrel song , ‘I have got tired of this man.’ The sentence chos thos pas rgyud grol nas_/_khrel yod ngo tsha shes was explained to me as: Having understood the doctrine, and having been delivered (saved), I am now weary of the world, have renounced the world, know the world for vanity, have turned away from it. For J.'s khrel gad , ‘scornful laughter’, the synonym khrel dgod was given to me, as well as the explanation ‘a laugh to make the other feel ashamed,’ ‘to make another feel small.’ We may therefore think of ironic, sarcastic, malicious laughter, or of derision and Schadenfreude. khrel gad rgyab pa , to laugh at another, at the expense of another, in order to make him ridiculous. This word khrel furnishes a very striking test of the present state of Tibetan lexicography, the word gdan will furnish another.
For words like these a comprehensive collection of authentic illustrations is imperative before finer shades and the exact range of meanings can be fixed. ngo tsha , commonly translated as ‘shame,’ a synonym for khrel , is a similarly uncertain word. Compare the translations in J. and S. Ch. D. of this same sentence: khrel ba dang ngo tsha ba med , J.: ‘he has no shame nor dread’; S. Ch. D.: ‘he has no shame or modesty.’
khrel med see khrel ba .
khrel gzhung med see khrel ba .
khrel yod pa see khrel ba .
khrel sems can see khrel ba .
khrod see gangs ri'i khrod 'di na and 'brog .
mkhyen pa see mkhyen brtse .
mkhyen brtse , 55. J.'s queried mkhyen brtse , quoted from Gyal-rabs: ‘prob.: omniscient-merciful,’ cannot with any certainty be decided from this passage.
Desg. has mkhyen brtse* = thugs rje = ‘knowledge of the heart, i.e. pity, mercy.’
S. Ch. D. ‘omniscient mercy.’
According to my teachers these are two different words here, knowledge and mercy; not a compound. mkhyen pa is here hon. form of shes pa to know. But a subst. mkhyen is not recorded in the Dicts. Desg. has a mkhyen pa = shes pa = rig pa ‘science, knowledge,’ and S. Ch. D. also gives mkhyen pa as ‘knowledge.’ In compounds mkhyen has usually the verbal value of ‘knowing.’ The entries s.v. mkhyen in the Dicts. need careful comparison and deserve close study.
mkhyen pa is often used in an emphatic sense, to know all, to know through and through, to know with supernatural knowledge (as, for instance, to know what happens from a distance), cf. the English adj. ‘knowing.’
The shades of meaning: wise, learned, intelligent, sensible, careful, cautious, clever, need further analysis.
'khrug pa , 35. The value of this word is clear from the Dicts., but there is a difficulty in choosing suitable English words to fit each case in rendering. Such words as the following may be found useful under various circumstances: to be disturbed, upset, disordered (cf. disordered brain), unbalanced, deranged, convulsed, in turmoil, tumultuous (a soul in tumult), in revolt, turbulent, wild, seething, in uproar, in the throes of (passion, etc.).
And even so none of the above expressions furnishes an easy, idiomatic and close rendering for rgyud khong nas 'khrugs pa'i mi , the man whose very character is an utter chaos.
'khur ba , 21. Ordinarily to carry, but here to carry back, i.e. to repay, render, return.
Example: pha ma'i drin 'khur dgos , You must repay your parents their kindness. The verb 'jal ba , primarily ‘to weigh’, is equally so used; see J. s.v. 4. For the above example the word lan would ordinarily be inserted, pha ma'i drin lan 'khur dgos , but this would lessen the force of the illustration for our purpose as lan means here ‘return,’ and drin lan*, ‘a kindness in return.’ The above sentence can be expressed in three ways: pha ma'i drin (with or without lan ) 'khur (or 'jal , or log ) dgos .
gangs ri ma , title. Mother Snow Mountain. The affixes to ri are according to J. bo and ga ; Desg. adds ngo ; S. Ch.
D. only bo ; Bell and Henderson no affix. Of these bo gives a definite sense of greatness to the mountain. (See S. Ch. D., Grammar, Introduction, p. 18). Here the particle ma is not an inherent part of the substantive, but is added to give a feminine sense to the word, which here means something like ‘Mother Mountain,’ the big mountain being as it were the mother of all smaller hills and heights around it. My informants were definitely of opinion that, here, ‘Mother Mountain’ and not ‘Lady Mountain’ was meant. So we should not understand the expression as ‘Her Majesty or Ladyship the Snow Mountain.’ The meaning though grammatically important remains better neglected in the translation.
gangs ri'i khrod 'di na , 25. In this snow-mountain-mass, i.e. monastery. ri khrod as monastery in J. s.v. ri but not s.v. khrod . Bell has ri khrod as ‘cell (of hermit).’
Here the expression seems rather to indicate Gendundub's own monastery (be it Daipung, Tashilhunpo or Namgyalchöde) than Galdan, spoken of in the second verse. See Schulemann, Gesch. der Dalailamas, pp. 92 fll. See 'brog and shar .
go lag see skyo ba .
gol sa , 33. J. 'gol sa , error, mistake. In Desg. 'gol sa or 'gol ba'i gnas , solitary spot (s.v. 'gol ) and lam gol (s.v. gol ), ‘has lost his way’; and also 'gol sar gnas su to put apart; 'gol lam , a separate road, a side road (route détournée). According to Desg. only the past form of 'gol ba , i.e. gol ba , means to have erred, gone astray, both physically and morally. S. Ch. D. copies J., but adds to J.'s 'gol sa , the place where two roads separate: ‘so as to create doubt in the mind regarding the right path.’ Schroeter (p. 451a) has two entries 'gol ba , ‘remote,’ and 'gol ba'i gnas , ‘a closet.’ J. has the latter expression as ‘a hermitage,’
and Desg., as above, ‘solitary spot.’ In our passage lam gol sa does not mean ‘the mistake as to the road,’ or Anglice ‘the error of his ways.’
In our passage lam gol has to be taken together in the sense of log lam = lam log = lam ngan , the wrong road (in a religious sense, in contrast to the lam mthon po of l. 31). lam gol sa is here to be understood as a ‘wrong-road-place,’ as the spot or place (sa = sa cha ) which is, or proves to be, the wrong road, i.e. the place where one realizes that the road on which one is, is the wrong road, or, perhaps better, that the road is a wrong road (= place) to be in, a wrong-road-spot, indeed.
The meanings, recorded in the Dicts. for compounds with or without initial 'a of 'gol ba , seem logical, as one who has separated himself from the road, is astray, is mistaken, is (in moral or intellectual matters) in the wrong, in error.
Note this example of the use of the verb: lan rig pa bsgrims nas rgyab ma gtogs 'gol yong ngo , answer very carefully otherwise you will make a mistake.
[rig pa bsgrims nas , ‘having twisted, squeezed, screwed up your brains??’ = adv., carefully, attentively.]
gos lag see skyo ba .
glu see mgur ma .
glud , 40. Ransom. Is here rather glud tshab , well defined by S. Ch. D., s.v. The meaning of glud tshab is probably ‘the ransom (which is thrown to the evil spirit) as a substitute for, representative of (the person on whose behalf the offering is made),’ J.'s mi glud ‘a man's image which in his stead is cast
away in the gtor ma*,’ a ransom in effigy. There are, however, uses of glud in which the primary sense is perhaps rather ‘effigy’ than ‘ransom.’ In a ritual describing the construction of the torma cake it is said that the sku glud (together with many other moulds) must be imprinted on the dough or paste. Here the word seems to mean no more than ‘a mould constituting an effigy of the body.’ Though all the torma-cake material is thrown away after it has served its purpose, these imprinted effigies do not seem to serve specially as ransoms like the glud tshab and mi glud quoted above.
As to J.'s queried kho mi glud yin (and the slightly different mi kho glud yin ), this is explained as follows. The first phrase means: he is a lü in human form (a man-lü, cf. werwolf; D. een lü in menschenvorm, menschelijke gedaante). mi kho means ‘that man, there (with a pointing out by word or finger).’ For instance: that man John, that king ko ko . ‘That man’ alone would be mi de . But the second phrase would mean: ‘that man so-and-so is a very devil.’ J.'s rendering of the first phrase as ‘he is a curse, an anathema, one deserving to be cursed’ seems too strong. Rather ‘an unmitigated nuisance,’ for, though harsh, it may be said by a mother of her own child when it is naughty and unruly. The sense seems to be ‘devil’ (as may also be applied to children or wicked grown-ups in English ‘they are true devils,’ D. ‘een paar baarlijke duivels’) and seems to be a case of meaning-shifting from result to cause (pale death!), the lü being the ransom thrown to the evil spirit, Anglice devil. The association does not seem to be that of worthlessness, hatefulness, something good for nothing, only fit to be thrown away like a lü.
As to the above King Koko, this is a facetious name applied (something like thingumbob) to such Tibetans as ape Chinese manners in dress and in other ways. ko ko is said to be a Chinese word for Tib. a jo or jo jo , elder brother. A Tibetan, strutting about in Darjeeling with Chinese cap and
coat may hear the sarcasm addressed to him: ko ko lags ga pa phebs kyi yin nam ‘Well Mr. Chinaman (or John Ch., Uncle Ch.) where are you going to?’ (‘Mossioo’ of the mid-Victorian Punch and music hall ditties).

dge ldan , 6. Clearly printed in both copies, not dga' ldan . This name, ‘the virtuous,’ seems to refer to the Gelukpa sect, though the monastery which is here meant is usually called dga' ldan . The relation between the two terms is not quite clear. Grünwedel, in his ‘Mythologie des Buddhismus,’ etc., p. 72, speaks of ‘das Kloster dGa-ldan oder dGe-ldan.’ Günther Schulemann in ‘Die Geschichte der Dalailamas,’ p. 65, speaks of the ‘Schule, die zuerst dGa-ldan-pa, dann aber dGe-ldan-pa oder dGe-lugs-pa, ‘die Tugendsekte’, genannt wurde.’ Modern Tibetans seem to know only the name dga' ldan for the famous monastery.

mgur ma , title. Its hon. form is gsung mgur . As a single word the affix ma is required, which may disappear in compounds. Bell gives as meaning of mgur ma ‘religious song,’ Henderson ‘hymn.’
As J. points out, the profane song is glu and the religious song mgur ma . A synonym for glu is gzhes (not in the three Dicts. but in Bell and Henderson s.v. song).
S. Ch. D.'s glu gzhes ‘sportive song’ is not supported by the data in J. or Desg., nor by my informants. They take the
second part of this compound as a misprint for gzhes and hold that glu gzhes is a double-form with the meaning of either of its parts: song. The word mgur ma has one honorific form, gsung mgur . The words glu and gzhes have each various hon. forms: gsung gzhes (recorded in Bell) and gsung glu . Desg. has a gsung mgur , pleasant song, but my oral information does not support this special meaning.
Note the difference between J. skyid glu (s.v. skyid ), ‘song of joy,’ and Desg. id. s.v. glu ‘chant érotique.’
In Redslob's translation of the Psalms into classical Tibetan, the word gsung mgur is used for psalm.

'gye ba and 'gyed pa , 38. Attention must be drawn to the fact that Desg. identifies 'gyed pa with 'gye ba as against J.'s distinction between the two forms as neutral and active. Also that Desg.'s explanation of g.yul 'gyed etc., as ‘to put (the

rga ba , 33. To be old, the state of being old, old age. Example ske rga na 'chi'i sdug bsngal yod , ‘the being born, growing old, being ill, dying are sorrows,’ or ‘birth, old age, illness and death are sorrowful.’ Cf. the treatment of the first four words in J. rgas pa'i , with following verb, to be translated as ‘of old age,’ literally: of (belonging to, attendant on) having become old; for instance, the joys, sorrows, etc., of the state of having become old (of old age) = rgas pa'i skyid po (or sdug po ). This is not the subst. rgas or rgas po of Desg. J. treats rga ba as a verb with rgas as a past tense, taking rgad pa and rgan pa as adjectives from which the usual substantives in po , mo , etc., are made. Desg. gives the four forms rga , rgad , rgan and rgas
as substantives and has no verb ‘to be old.’ J.'s analysis seems the more accurate one. J.'s rgas ka ‘old age’ is absent in Desg., whilst this latter has a rgas without affix as ‘old man,’ ‘old age.’ This word S. Ch. D. has as = rga ba ‘old, ripe’; whilst he adds rgas pa = rgad po ‘aged, old; exhausted, infirm; an old man.’ This group needs proper quotations for final settlement.
My oral information on some of these points is as follows: The use of rgas alone, as ‘old, ripe’ is denied. rgas pa does not mean rgad po ‘old,’ because rgas pa requires a lo ‘grown old in years’ in that sense. As an independent adjective, however, it means ‘worn out, exhausted, thin, lean, aged, grown older,’ and is in that case an equivalent for rgad po . Troubles make a man rgas pa ‘age him’; make him as if old. Age makes a man rgad po , old, i.e. really old. For the use of rgas ka the following two illustrations were given: rgas ka'i dus la las 'di 'dra ma byed ‘don't do such work (or things: or don't behave in that manner) in your old age;’ rgas ka shi ba'i dus la bsam blo ngan pa ma thong , ‘don't think bad (evil) thoughts in your old age when (whilst) death is drawing near.’

rgyan pa and brgyan pa , 54. The treatment of these words in the Dicts. seems unsatisfactory. None of the Dicts. give a passive verb rgyan pa or brgyan pa ‘being adorned, being decked out, embellished,’ etc. J. has only rgyan as a subst. ‘ornament, decoration,’ and a verb brgyan pa ‘to adorn, decorate, provide with.’ According to this his own example nya mgo sa yis brgyan pa should not mean, as he says, ‘the letter nya (nya ) being provided with an S above it’ (= snya ), but rather something like ‘to adorn the letter nya with a sa as a topletter.’
Desg. knows a verb rgyan pa or rgyan rgyab (or byed or bkod ) with the meaning of ‘to adorn,’ with a past tense brgyan , ‘ornavi, ornatus, orné,’ whatever that means. He and J. quote also a rgyan gyis brgyan pa ‘adorned,’ in which the rgyan has clearly a substantival value, like in rgyan med pa , ‘without adornment, unadorned.’
S.v. brgyan Desg. says: ‘praet. verbi rgyan par , ornatus, et v. act. ornare, orné, orner,’ and he adds brgyan pa or cha ‘ornament.’ Bell has rgyan cha for ornament. But J. knows no brgyan pa or cha as substantives and refers expressly to the unprefixed rgyan for the substantives. He further equates rgyan cha and rgyan rnams ‘ornaments’ (plural). Under 'dogs pa , ‘to put on,’ we find further rgyan 'dogs pa , to put on gay clothes, finery (s.v. rgyan , the same expression is translated as ‘to adorn one's self,’) and rgyan bzang po btags pa , ‘beautifully attired’ (Mil.). If these translations are idiomatically true we should expect
(ba) rkyan to have a wider sense than the English ornament, rather anything beautiful or fine, whether ornaments (in the sense of trinkets) or not. The word adornment would fit better. (Cf. D. tooi, G. Schmuck.)
Desg. gives no example of rgyan pa with a clearly active value of the verb ‘to ornament,’ but both in J. and Desg. such examples are given under brgyan pa . Desg. gives as synonyms legs byed and mdzes byed and it is a question whether in these expressions byed can have the neuter sense of ‘to act as’ = ‘to be’ (like in rgyal po byed pa ). S. Ch. D. (who has several misprints in his syns. for rgyan ) quotes s.v. 'god pa (292b) a brgyan dgod pa , ‘to arrange ornaments (tastefully); to decorate, adorn, to construct or adjust grammatical forms, sentences, (Zam.).’ This latter use of brgyan is evidently the clue to the expression, quoted elsewhere by Desg. and S. Ch. D.: rgyan mkhan po , ala.mkarapa.n.ditaala.mkaarapa.n.dita, one versed in rhetoric, a clever orator. The equation rgyan pa = bzhag pa (in the modern language, v. Bell, to put, place), given by S. Ch. D. is denied by both my teachers, though confirmed by Desg.; they know of no Tibetan word of this spelling and sound with the meaning bejewelled, adorned, decorated, as is the correct translation of the Sk. equivalent cited, ma.n.dita. Yet may rgyan (pa ) perhaps mean ‘an ornamented object’, hence ‘die, dice’; hence again Desg. ‘objets mêlés pour tirer les sorts’, and lastly ‘stake’ (in gambling) and ‘lot’? This first meaning is not in the Dicts. but would settle the question discussed a few lines lower down, and explain those combinations with rgyan which refer to gambling and divination. In connection with the immediately following articles in S. Ch. D., rgyan bzhag mkhan*, ‘one who joins in a wager, gambler’ [one who puts up his jewels, ornaments for
a stake?], and rgyan dor ba or bzhag pa , ‘a dice-rogue, a gamester, one who throws dice,’ etc., it should be ascertained whether there is a Tibetan word with rgyan which means die, dice, or whether the combinations refer to the staking of ornaments and jewels in gambling.
S.v. brgyan pa S. Ch. D. gives no news, treating this word, however, as a verb, and referring to rgyan for the subst.
As a result of this little investigation we come to the conclusion that it is legitimate to inquire whether there is not a Tibetan verb rgyan pa (more likely than brgyan pa ) with the passive or neuter sense of ‘being decked out, being ornamented or adorned, showing gaily.’ What would render such a word exactly in English is difficult to see, unless we coin a verb ‘to splendiferate,’ but D. pronken (pronken in vollen luister) comes near to it. Other related words would be: to blaze forth, to shine out, to cut a dash, or else to swagger, to swank, to preen, to strut, or again to be graced with or by, to show forth, etc., but especially ‘to display’ in the technical zoological sense.
An instructive illustration in this matter is furnished by the following two sentences, both with the same meaning: thang ka ri mos brgyan 'dug , or thang ka 'di la ri mos brgyan 'dug , of which the best idiomatic translation is: O, what a fine picture!; how fine is the painting (drawing) of (in) (this) picture!
But the psychological translation is in the first case: ‘This picture is by-lines-(fine)-displaying’, and in the second case: ‘To this picture there is a by-the-lines-(drawings)-ornamentation (or display).’

rgyal ba , 6. According to J., III, also ‘superior, excellent, eminent.’ rnam par rgyal ba , ‘most excellent, illustrious.’ This may be the meaning here. Whether there is a connection between the word as used here and the rgyal ba title of the Dalai Lamas may be left undecided.

sgo , 39, 40. Door. Though the average Tibetan house (if it be not a mere hut) has two doors, a front door and a back door, they are not on a principle located in the eastern and western sides of the house. For the text the words east and west have no special significance; they are simply used dpe 'dra po , by way of speech, as an example, illustration or comparison.
The front (main, public) door is called gzhung sgo or rgya (or rgyal ) sgo . The first word is interpreted as the ‘main,’ ‘public,’ or ‘middle’ door; the second as the ‘wide’ or ‘royal’ door. The back door is called ltagsgo ltag sgo (in J. s.v. ltag pa ), which is explained as ‘the door for horses and cattle.’ The skyed sgo quoted by J., p. 29b, is unknown to my informants. They only know a skyesgo skye sgo , ‘the door leading to birth, or re-birth.’

dag snang , 43. J.'s entry under this entry is as follows: “dag (pa'i*) snang (ba ) Schr. ‘good opinion’ (?), prob.: a pure, sound view or knowledge Glr.; in Mil. it has a similar meaning.” He adds an oral sentence: “*dhag-ná&ndota; jón-wa* C. to lead a holy life.” (sic. jón = jó&ndota;?) Schroeter has (135b): “dag snang , a good opinion, a good conception of any thing, a conceit, a thought.” [Based on an Italian ‘concetto’?] He has two further entries ‘dag pa'i snang ba , to form a good
opinion of any individual,’ and ‘dag snang spyong (read: sbyong ) ba , to form a good opinion, or to conceive well of any one.’
In our passage we are inclined to take snang as snang ba , as ‘view, thought, idea, conception,’ etc., and sbyong ba = ‘to exercise, practise, perform’, or even ‘to entertain, cherish (thoughts).’ dag we take as dag pa , ‘pure’—the connection with thought not the opposite of false, erroneous, but of bad, cruel, unkind. So here the expression seems to mean ‘to think with goodwill, with kindness (of others),’ not the colloquial ‘to have a good opinion of, to think well of.’ To think ‘good’ is here the opposite of to think ‘evil,’ but the idiomatic value of the expression ‘to think well of’ (as the opposite of ‘to think poorly of’) would make the latter rendering misleading. The real value, then, of the expression as used in this passage, seems to be: ‘to think good, kind thoughts of,’ i.e. purely, or saintly in the sense of kindly, lovingly, benevolently, in a friendly manner, with sympathy, but not, as J. seems to suggest, intellectually correct. We may expand the rendering into ‘with a holy mind, with thoughts of saintliness, thinking saintly thoughts.’ Compare J.'s colloquial phrase quoted above. So, as to the interpretation of the line in which the compound occurs, we take it that it means to enjoin, in contrast with the previous line in which it is said that beings in general must be thought of with kindness, that religious people (instead of the mere laymen) must be thought of in a still better, higher manner, namely with holiness and saintliness.
One of my informants was first inclined to take dag snang sbyong ba as ‘to teach, to preach the true knowledge.’ Though he later on sided with the explanation adopted above, the opinion should be recorded, but it should be added that a second informant rejected this view of the first one.
Attention should be drawn to the meaning of snang dag , ‘the soul’ (with spellings snang and nang ; dag , rtags , brtag , stag , s. J.). Also the curious expression ‘to be indifferent’ snang dag ma btang ba , S. Ch. D.; and snang dag mi byed pa , Bell. These expressions not in Desg.

The latter is something like pidgin-English ‘number one’ or the kitchen Malay equivalent ‘nommer satu.’ Other equations are gcig po (or pu ), also rang , the Anglo-Indian ‘pukka.’
The word dwangs may mean soup or gravy in the following case, when there is question of singling out the liquid portion from a mixture of broth and liquid. The primary meaning seems in that case rather to be liquid as contrasted to solid. nga la dwangs blugs rogs gnang = give me (only) the liquid (not the solid stuff), pour out to me (only) the liquid. But this dwangs has no final ma . A common word for soup which is not in the Dicts. is ‘rü thang’, probably rus thang , or thang alone. This latter word is in J. with the meaning of ‘potion’, a medical term, and in S. Ch. D. as ‘potion, plain decoction, or mixture to be drunk after a medicinal pill has been taken.’ The word rus thang means originally bone-soup, but has acquired also the more general meaning ‘soup.’ thang can be applied to meat-soup, sha khu , but sha thang cannot be used. It might be that thang and dwangs are really the same word.

don re chung , 40. ‘Exceedingly stupid, meaningless, useless, silly, senseless.’ The particle re has an emphatic value, but it is difficult to define its precise scope in English. Oral information is vague on the subject, and seems to point towards a possibility that the re is a syllable of exclamation or turns the expression, of which it forms part, into an exclamation. don re chung . ‘Oh, how silly!’ An equivalent is don chung chung yin = don med . don chung alone is not used, and don chung chung demands a final red or yin .
S. Ch. D. (502a) translates khyod bod rnams snying re rje as: ‘I pity you, ye Tibetans’; perhaps better ‘What a pity, O ye Tibetans.’ Compare the list of words with wedged-in re in J. s.v. re p. 533b.
drin che ba , 16. Also drin chen , adjective ‘kind.’ According to S. Ch. D. also ‘very kind, great boon, and the great or greatest benefactor.’ S. Ch. D.'s wording is unsatisfactorily indefinite and his examples, taken from J., fit the text badly.
J. does not define the combination drin che ba though he has an example bka' drin che ba with the meaning ‘greatest benefit.’ Two colloquial examples are: drin che ba'i yab yum gnyis , ‘the two (very) kind parents,’ and mi 'di drin chen yin , that man is (very) kind.
In form drin che ba is a comparative, ‘kinder.’ chen po is one of those adjectives which have a comparative and superlative of their own as:
Great. Many. Good. Small. Bad.
positive chen po mang po yag po chung chung sdug po
comparative che ba mang ba (or nga ) yag ga chung nga sdug ga
superlative che shos mang shos yag shos chung shos sdug shos
In practice, however, as shown by the above examples, the form is used for an ordinary quality in the positive degree though implying an amount of abundance or fullness of the quality referred to. Bell (p. 33) and Hannah (p. 129) have described these degrees of comparison. Short and partial notes in S. Ch. D.'s grammar (p. 31) and Henderson (p. 23). See J. Dict. s.v. shos , p. 564. drin che, J. 262b (as equal to drin can ) is not acknowledged by my informants.
drin che is objected to by my teachers because they say it never occurs alone but requires a final ba , except in the superlative form drin che shos which, of course, is another thing. See, however, S. Ch. D. bka' drin che , p. 654, J. p. 13. As to the chen or chen po in many Tibetan adjectives, this is better regarded as an enclitic particle, exactly corresponding to the English termination -ful. As little as the English -ful really
means ‘full’, does the Tibetan chen (po ) as a termination of adjectives really mean ‘great.’
Bell has drin chen po for ‘kind.’
The word drin lan and its uses merit a separate inquiry. In this place we shall limit ourselves to stating that the entry gratitude (S. Ch. D., Ramsay, Schroeter) seems incorrect. The confusion has most likely come about because a drin lan is an answer to kindness (return gift, etc.) and so betokens gratitude.
drin chen (po ) see drin che ba .
drin ji bzhin , 21. Ellipse for: according to (or, in the measure of) whatever kindness (you have shown to me).
drin lan see drin che ba .

gdug pa , 35. The three Dicts. are not at one as to the exact shades of meaning of gdug pa .
J. has, subst.: ‘anything hurtful, or any injury, mischief, harm, done.’
Desg., subst.: ‘dommage, perte, mal.’
S. Ch. D. no substantive.
J., adj. (= gdug pa can*), ‘noxious, mischievous, dangerous.’ Desg., adj. only gdug pa can , not gdug pa alone: nuisible (noxious), and a gdug = gdog , deteriorated.
S. Ch. D., adj.: gdug po , vicious, mischievous, deleterious, poisonous.
In J. and S. Ch. D. further applied meanings as: wild, hideous (screams); ferocity (in beasts), deleterious (smell), fierce (woman).
In our passage the expression gdug sems can may be rendered by malign, wicked, evil, evil-minded, spiteful, with sufficient correctness.
gdug pa can see gdug pa .

gdung ba see gdung dbyangs .
gdung dbyangs , Colophon. J. renders this word as ‘a song expressive of longing or of grief, an elegy (Mil.)’; but this definition is not quite typical of our present poem. S. Ch. D. has ‘a song of longing grief.’ J.'s example mos gus gdung ba dpag med skye , where gdung ba means (spiritual) love, seems to point out to a meaning more apposite here. So we would prefer a translation: paean, hymn of praise (D. lofzang), or psalm instead of elegy. Other words to be considered: song of thanksgiving, memorial song, lament, plaintive song (jammerklacht?), memorial verses, an in memoriam, a memorial, etc. See also dbyangs .
The dge rgan, however, explains the word indeed in J.'s manner, but states that the longing and grief are not the worldly sentiments but religious ones. The longing and grief are concerned with the sorrows of the world and a yearning after spiritual realities, but not with the memory of the three teachers mentioned in the poem. If this is true, the above hypothesis is likely to be a wrong one and in my translation of the colophon the words there used should in that case rather run ‘as a song of yearning for the higher life’ (cf. the G. ‘Weltschmerz’).
gdog see gdug pa .
'dul thabs , 37. Steps, measures, to subdue or tame, etc. 'dul thabs byed pa , to take such measures.
'dogs pa see rgyan pa .
'dren pa, 20. (Fut. drang ). If the lcags kyu (see kyu ) is here to be thought of as a goad (like the one of the mahout) then the verb should be understood as sub J. 2, ‘to conduct, lead, guide’ (by prodding). My teachers take it as ‘to draw,’ or ‘pull.’ Pictorial representations might decide the point. My teachers think rather of a rod with a hook at the end, like the episcopal staff, and not of angling with a fishhook or prodding with a goad.
sdug yus , 33. Or simply yus , here: ‘the loss of temper, wrath, angry explosion or outburst.’ This sense is not given in the Dicts., though J.'s 4, ‘ardour, fervour, transport’ comes near it. sdug yus is the same as yus , but for the fact that the former word shows the cause, an outburst on account of trouble, vexation, worry, pain, sorrow. (sdug ) yus bshad (ston or byed ) pa = to show (or to lose) one's temper, to flare up, to burst out, to break loose, to explode in anger, wrath. pha ma la sdug yus ma bshad , ‘don't show temper to your parents.’ dpon la yus ma bshad , ‘don't lose your temper before (or with) the master.’ de ring khos nga la yus mang po bstan song , ‘to-day he has entirely lost his temper before (or to) me.’ It is synonymous, in this sense, with the word 'u thug which is also dealt with inadequately in the Dicts. q.v. mi su la yang 'u thug ma ston , ‘don't lose your temper to anyone, to whomsoever.’ khyod kyis 'u thug bshad dgos pa'i don med , ‘there is no reason (no need, or it is senseless) to lose your temper.’ (Cf. D. uitvallen, uitvaren, uitvoeteren, opstuiven, uitbarsten.)
gnam la snyeg 'dra ba , 2. Either ‘as if rising towards the

rnal 'byor sogs , 9. I have not received an explanation of the ‘etc.’ (sogs ) in this place and I ignore what kind of category is alluded to here. It seems not probable that the '18 classes of science’ can be meant, which, in the Mahāvyutpatti (Ed. M.A.S.B.), form group XXIV, p. 20. Group L, (p. 59), furnishes more likely material, but Yoga is missing in it.
snang dag see dag snang .
dpal ldan , 56. ‘Glorious, noble,’ also ‘having abundance.’ Twice mentioned in J.'s article but not translated, perhaps because the meaning is so evident. Curious that neither Desg. nor J. specially cite this compound to which S. Ch. D. gives 7 lines, besides mentioning several combinations.
dpal bla med , 52. Is this one word?
dpal 'bar ba , 53. ‘Glory- or splendour-burning,’ i.e. ‘to blaze with glory,’ or, more tamely, ‘to be famous, renowned, celebrated’; the latter quoted by J. from Cs. s.v. 'bar ba (It may also be taken as glory-spreading, i.e. getting more famous). Desg. quotes a geographical name dpal 'bar , Chinese Pienpa. The expression is not in Desg. or S. Ch. D., and in J. only as taken from Cs., so that the latter's explanation needs verification. The literal translation ‘to blaze with glory’ fits here better.
Colloquially 'bar ba is ‘to thrive, to prosper, to do well.’ 'bar 'dug , ‘he is doing well, is well-to-do, thriving.’ 'bar
song , he has become rich, has made a success of his life, has come out top dog, has made good, has become wealthy, opulent, is safe, got his ship home, has ‘got there,’ made his pile, is now a man of position. (Fr. est arrivé. D. is binnen, heeft zijn schaapjes op het drooge.)
dpe , 53. Here dpe = dpe byad or dpe byad bzang po , technically ‘the eighty symmetrical parts, proportions, or points of beauty’ (Cs., Mahāvyutpatti); or beauties, lesser signs (de Harlez); proportions (Schiefner). See the references under mtshan and mtshan dpe . J. (s.v. dpe*, p. 327b) gives the full expression ‘the eighty physical perfections of Buddha,’ dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu , and dpe byad alone ‘proportion, symmetry, beauty.’ J. has the entry dpe ‘symmetry, harmony, beauty (in certain phrases)’ but S. Ch. D. omits this. Our passage is an example of this use, but the syllable dpe is really an abbreviation here and not a full and independent word. Desg. seems to be mistaken in saying: dpe byed (sic, misprint for byad ) or mtshan dpe , ‘proportion, symmetry, the 80 marvels of the body of the Buddha.’ So dpe byad can means indeed ‘symmetrical, showing 80 marvels,’ but these meanings would not be applicable to mtshan dpe can which could only mean ‘showing the 32 signs and 80 beauties.’
For the rest Desg.'s 2nd article s.v. dpe adds to J.'s data, and his dpe srol and dpe tshul ‘custom, rule, example’ are new. In Desg. ‘custom, rule’ tally with S. Ch. D. ‘way of doing, method’ which J. has as ‘pattern, model,’ but which he translates more freely in his examples. J. s.v. byad ‘proportion, symmetry, beauty,’ quotes a dpe byad from the Dzl. in the same
sense. According to this dpe would be equal to byad which seems improbable and is denied by my informants. An example of the use of dpe tshul is the following: de ring sang gi dgon pa'i lo gsar gyi 'cham de dang po'i dpe tshul red , the new year's dance of now-a-days in the monastery is in imitation of the old way, is after the ancient pattern, the old manner, follows the old example. dpe tshul is here not exactly lugs srol ‘custom’ but rather: ‘(with) the (ancient) method (as) an example.’
Note the use of dang po'i in the above example as ‘old, ancient.’

dpe byad see dpe .

dpe tshul see dpe .
